crowd.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a large group of people who have gathered together to do something, for example to watch something or protest about something
crowd.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: There were crowds of shoppers in the street.
A vast crowd gathered in the main square.
She mingled with the crowd of guests, exchanging greetings.
Saturday’s game was watched by a capacity crowd (=the maximum number of people that a sports ground etc can hold).
Troops fired tear gas and shots to disperse a crowd of 15,000 demonstrators.
crowd.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a group of people who know each other, work together etc
crowd.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I didn’t know him; he wasn’t one of the usual crowd.
crowd.translation[0].note_box[0].section: a crowd gathers
A large crowd had gathered to watch the procession go past.
a crowd cheers
The crowd cheered as the team came onto the pitch.
a crowd roars
As the band appeared the crowd roared in approval.
a crowd surges forward
Police officers began to lose control and the crowd surged forward.
a crowd disperses/breaks up
Seeing there would be no more entertainment, the crowd began to disperse.
a crowd lines the street/route etc
A crowd lined the street to catch a glimpse of the president.
attract/draw a crowd
The ceremony is expected to draw a crowd of more than 1,000.
pull a crowd/pull in the crowds
Low prices always pull in the crowds.
disperse/break up a crowd
A few warning shots were fired in an attempt to disperse the crowd.
mingle/mix with the crowd
The actors went outside to talk to and mingle with the crowd.
a big/large/huge crowd
A big crowd is expected tomorrow for the final match.
a good crowd
There was a good crowd on the first night of the show.
a capacity crowd
The band performed brilliantly to a capacity crowd.
a sellout crowd
The team won in front of a sellout crowd of 17,765.
a record crowd
They were playing before a record crowd of 50,000.
a bumper crowd
As usual there was a bumper crowd at the festival.
a crowd of people
I pushed my way through the crowd of people.
a crowd of onlookers
A crowd of onlookers had gathered to see what all the fuss was about.
crowd.translation[0].note_box[1].section: a large number of people together in one place
The exhibition is expected to attract large crowds of visitors.
mob
a crowd of noisy and violent people who are difficult to control
The mob set fire to cars and buildings.
mass
a very large crowd which is not moving and which is very difficult to move through
the mass of people in the station
horde
a large crowd of people, especially people who are behaving in a way that you disapprove of or that annoys you
the hordes of tourists on the island
droves
a crowd of people – used especially when you are talking about a crowd of people who move from one place to another
The public came in droves to see the event.
throng
a very large crowd
A great throng had gathered to listen to his speech.
flock
a large group of people of the same type, especially when they have a leader
A flock of children were being shown through the museum.
pack
a group of people of the same type, especially a group you do not approve of
A pack of reporters shouted questions.
swarm
a large crowd of people who are moving quickly in many directions in a very uncontrolled way
a swarm of children in the playground
crush
a crowd of people who are pressed close together
There was such a crush on the Metro this morning.
multitude
a very large number of people, especially ordinary people
The Emperor came out to speak to the multitude.
crowd.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if people crowd somewhere, they gather together in large numbers, filling a particular place
crowd.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Hundreds of people crowded into the church for the funeral.
We all crowded round the table.
the rapid spread of infection in areas where people are crowded together
crowd.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if people or things crowd a place, there are a lot of them there
crowd.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Range after range of mountains crowd the horizon.
crowd.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if thoughts or ideas crowd your mind or memory, they fill it, not allowing you to think of anything else
crowd.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Strange thoughts and worries were crowding his mind.
crowd.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to make someone angry by moving too close to them
crowd.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Stop crowding me – there’s plenty of room.
crowd.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to make someone angry or upset by making too many unfair demands on them
